posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57033873
The scary thing is that these arrows are probably not far off the Operational objectives of the Vatnik General Staff.

Tell me though, did you bother to look at logistical capability for each of these axes of desired advance?

Where do the railheads and road networks run, and how far behind the FEBA are they? Are they in range of arty, HIMARS, MLRS and GLDBS?
Say you’d need your rail sidings 50-60 miles away, that means your resupply trucks have a 60 mile one-way trip to deliver 3-5 tons of cargo just to the existing front line area. Then, (assuming they don’t get zapped), they have to return to the railhead.
That’s a lot of fuel. Better make room for that on the train, which means less bullets, beans and Band-aids for your frontline Vatniks.

So then let’s say you make significant gains on one or two axes of these prospective advances…25 miles on one and 50 miles on another.

Now you’ve just compounded your logistical headache, because railroad tracks are supremely static things, and your forces that made these advances are going to be badly in need of resupply and reinforcement lest they be flanked and surrounded.

Professionals study logistics.

>>57038773
I think the more likely explanation is that recent Western arms transfer announcements are coming in March-April at the earliest and their leadership realizes they need to liquidate this war before that happens. Even back when Russia had a more modern fleet it would have been at a disadvantage against NATO tanks. We saw what happened when T-64s and T-72s went up against Abrams 30 years ago. The tanks currently being transferred are just the beginning and NATO has far, far deeper and generally better preserved armored vehicle reserves than Russia does. The USA alone has 2,000 Bradleys, almost as many as Russia's BMP-1s in storage, And say what you will about a Bradley but there isn't a single non retarded human being who would rather be in a BMP-1.

The longer the war goes the more it will favor Ukraine provided western countries continue to have the stomach for it. And it's not like we're really suffering, I think Ukraine is getting less than 0.1% of western GDP at this point. USA is gearing up 155mm shell factories for war scale production so not even the artillery advantage will remain in favor of Russia if this war goes to 2024-2025.

posts.com: I have been shooting the same Colt A2 Sporter 2 carbine since I was 8 in 2000 (dad bought the rifle new in the late 80s, gave it to me on my 18th birthday in 2010) and that gun comes to the range with me every time I go shooting and after all of these years and tens of thousands of rounds through it do you know how many times the windage knob got bumped and/or accidentally adjusted? Zero times. I can’t tell you how many miles I’ve put in tromping around the woods with that gun on my back at my parents house, or how many times I’ve gone hiking or camping and have taken that gun with me to goof off with in the mountains. That gun has seen much more than just bench shooting at the range and not once has it ever lost zero or had the windage knob be accidentally moved. I don’t understand where that meme comes from, maybe if the rifle was issued to a bunch of lowest common denominator mouthbreather grunts who fiddle with their sights then sure, but that’s the fault of lack of training and lack of intelligence. It’s not the fault of the rifle and sure isn’t the fault of the near perfect sights.

>>57044498
It doesn't make sense to be making the decision based on battery dependence with how efficient Aimpoints are. Using the T2 for the sake of example - one battery can last for 5 years of constant operation. The typical shelf life of a CR2032 battery is 10 years. You can buy a six pack of Energizer CR2032s for around $10. Assuming the batteries become literally unusable after 10 years (they wouldn't), that'd still give you two batteries to make it the 10 years plus four back-ups. If your concern stems from an end of the world scenario where you expect batteries wouldn't be available for 10+ years I'd say you're probably fucked anyway, but I guess an LPVO would be a better choice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57045059
Where? A poorfag nato military could be using any number of things. A lot of underfunded nato militaries use G36s like latvia and spain, Ireland use AUGs, some countries like Greece and Turkey still use a lot of battle rifles like G3s, Baltic nato countries often still use soviet guns chambered in 5.56. But yeah, M4s are a safe bet.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57045059
Depends but older models of M16s like A2s and even A1s are still kicking around alongside base model M4s. What you also see a lot of are FALs and G3s, especially G3s because more than likely the nations that adopted G3s back then don't have the money to buy many new replacements. G36s and Augs aren't uncommon sights alongside old national 5.56 rifles like the FNC, AR-70/90, and even FAMASes. If I had to design a late 00s poorfag merc group they'd be using
>M60s or MAGs, stock config
>A2s or G3s
>ALICE or similar vintage LBE
>92s or Glocks
and if they have heavier assets
>Phantoms or Mirage IIIs
>M60s or Centurions
Basically what your average NATO army used roughly 40 odd years earlier

>>57043210
its not just metal technology, its chemistry, metallurgy, casting, and also the conceptual thought.

yes, you have a thrown rock. its not a big step to a thrown spear. but the next step is needing to find that a bent wood stick can store and release energy. Get that, you get a bow. But the jump from stored energy in a bow, to stored energy in a powder is a *massive* jump of chemistry, and it takes huge amounts of time to find a compound which will release the energy by conflagration, instead of combustion. When that's done, then you need to observe how that happens, and that the force needs to be contained. That takes metallurgy - casting, and forging technologies.
Only then, you can have a primitive single-shot gun.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57043320
now, the step from single-shot, to that glock OP talks about is an even bigger sequence of changes of thought - because you start with a cast bronze barrel or a froged iron one, and within about 150 years, you have revolvers. And you get rifling. but you're limited by black powder fouling, and by the fact each part is made to the individual weapon. So your first point is needing to develop standardised parts. And the secret to that is the screw thread. to make an accurate screwthread, you need the Maudsley Lathe, and that, quite simply is the most important part of the entire industrial revolution. And it was built on Whitworth's screw thread master which was an insanely complex master thread, hand-cut with files, accurate to a thousandth of an inch, which became the reference point all threads were cut from. without it, you couldnt have made the first screwthreads which enabled more accurate machines, etc, to enable the mass-production.
but to make that you needed the previous 500+ years of craftsmen making tools ever more accurately.
then you need the chemists, to be able to discover stuff like mercury fulminate, to enable a percussion cap, and that sort of stuff was hundreds of years of chemistry study, and one it was found, we had percussion cap firearms within 10 years.

there's so many tiny little incremental steps that OP is completely ignorant of, its really quite shameful.

Your example is bronze vs iron (also cold hammered bronze is actually superior to most iron, it's only later with steel or high quality iron that they became better. Issue was bronze was more expensive) but I offer this tidbit as just a bit of price perspective. If you want an interesting disparity in the price between gucci product and basic bitch milspec for swords, hugh Kennedy's armies of the caliphate book mentions how:

>Early caliphate abbasid soldier, on 60 dirhams a month could easily afford an egyptian model sword but would have to save 10 month's salary to buy a yemeni one (being the highest quality).

As for specifics:
>Yemeni (from Indian steel) being 50-100 dinars
>Sword from basra might be 2.5 dinars
>Damascus 15-20 dirhams
>Egyptian sword for 10 dirhams

From https://www.medievalislamiceconomy.uwo.ca/money_coinage/exchange_rates/index.html

In the 8th-9th century the dinar/dirham exchange rate is 1 dinar = 10-12 (and then 20-22 yay inflation) dirhams. So around 5-7 dinars a month for an abbasid soldier, meaning if he spent nothing on anything else no rent no food no nothing, it'd be +10 month's salary to buy a Yemeni sword.

To contextualize it for us, if you made 50,000 a year or 4167 a month imagine if some gucci-grade AR15 cost 41 thousand dollars.

Now I'm imagining hajj-point clapped out swords versus some tacticool'd gucci-grade Al-Rashidun١٥ sword.

>>57042472
150-200 tanks roughly equate to a mechanized division, 1 armored (2 tank battalions) and 2 mech (1 battalion each) brigades. That is a serious force.
>front too wide
You don’t use a spearhead formation along the entire front, you concentrate it to achieve breakthrough. As Guderian put it: nicht kleckern, klotzen!
The idea is to cut lines of communication and attack their supply and command infrastructure. As modern war takes enormous amounts of resources, the cut off troops have either to retreat quickly, leaving heavy equipment and supplies, or their combat value gets significantly diminished. You then can then proceed to either destroy the immobile enemy with artillery or starve them out while your troops keep exploiting the breakthrough, not allowing the enemy to get into new defensive positions.
The enemy might try to counter this using elastic defense.

>>56943577
>rechambered for 308 cetme
No it wasn't.
7.62 CETME isn't even a lower pressure cartridge, it's a lower recoiling cartridge, but it has the same pressure. The CETME cartridge used a light aluminum bullet pushed out with basically pistol powder. It was only made for the early CETME rifles to fire at full auto, not for bolt action rifles.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56948420
>What's the clasp mean?
A gloved finger jammed into the triggerguard tended to depress the catch and dump the magazine floorplate and magazine contents. Russians first put a sheet metal clasp around the lever, then switched to grinding the raised thumbpiece of the lever off from the inside of the triggerguard.

posts.com: This SMLE Mk.I*** is only rare on a curve compared to the glut of Mk.III*. A late 1911 manufacture date means this rifle was likely intended for the Royal Navy, who were still on the Mk.I* and had not yet adopted the Mk.III. It might have gone to the British Army during WW1; there's a possible unit marking on the buttstock and it was updated for Mk.VII ball (hence the additional **). In 1922 this rifle was sent to the newly formed Irish National Army (the pro-Treaty faction of the IRA) and so it saw service in the tail end of the Irish Civil War. These Irish rifles were sold as surplus to INTERARMS in 1960 and imported into the United States.

>>56982387
IIRC the "crossed rifles" on Carcanos is not an indicator of exceptional accuracy. It means that specific rifle was tested for accuracy and it met the minimum accuracy standards. All rifles were proof tested but not all rifles were accuracy tested because of time/budget constraints. If the selected rifle failed the accuracy test it meant there was a potential production problem and that batch of rifles made since the last recorded successful accuracy test had to be examined more carefully.

posts.com: Lads I can get a swiss 1889 for cheap, and I'm gonna start reloading soon. How hard is it to trim and load for the G90 type loads?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57011785
With my chamber I did not need to trim at all. These rifles were cut with a tremendous throat to accommodate the paper patched bullet so it’ll just depend on your example. Trimming is easy anyway. Loading GP90 is annoying as it’s small diameter paper patched. Loading the final iteration, the GP90/06/23 (non corrosive primer in 1906 and metallic jacketed bullet in 1923) is far easier. Use any 180-200gr .308 seated as far out as it’ll go and drop your GP11/7.5x55 load data by about 30% depending on the powder. They can be extremely accurate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57011785
>>57012593
I should add that I found flat based bullets to shoot much better, the long tapered throat doesn’t allow boat tails to bump up fully or evenly. I think it was sierra flat based round nosed 180s that shot best for me.

Reloading for the 89 chamber isn't hard. I just use regular 7.5x55 brass, the throat is generous enough you probably won't need to trim, unless you're loading paper patched bullets. Might just look a bit weird after firing, I trimmed mine down to 55mm just for good measure.
33.5g of imr4895 and a hornady 180g rnsp gets me 1moa accuracy out of my 89/96.
220g hornady rnsp are currently available and should be perfect.
Make sure to anneal your brass as your neck will expand a shit ton after firing

I should've said it is the same technically, near-exact was a poor choice of words. Egyptian heavy ball 8mm should be loaded to german spec, and have a muzzle velocity around 2500 fps. I used nice ass greek heavy ball ammo, also german spec, that does chrono around 2500. From what I've seen in guntuber vids and on forums pertaining to Egypt FN49s, they all experience the same thing. Bears do it. Bats do it. Even European hedgehogs do it. And now it turns out that early human beings may also have been at it. They hibernated, according to fossil experts.

Evidence from bones found at one of the world’s most important fossil sites suggests that our hominid predecessors may have dealt with extreme cold hundreds of thousands of years ago by sleeping through the winter.

The scientists argue that lesions and other signs of damage in fossilised bones of early humans are the same as those left in the bones of other animals that hibernate. These suggest that our predecessors coped with the ferocious winters at that time by slowing down their metabolisms and sleeping for months.

The conclusions are based on excavations in a cave called Sima de los Huesos – the pit of bones – at Atapuerca, near Burgos in northern Spain.

>>57046733
IF YOU could rewind the evolutionary clock millions of years, you might discover that your ancestors had a remarkable trait. It wouldn’t be obvious at first. But in certain conditions – if food were scarce or there were a cold snap – it is possible that their eyes would grow heavy and their bodies begin to slow until, eventually, they switched off entirely. They would be hibernating.

In this low-energy state, today’s hibernators can fend off a remarkable array of threats, from the inside and out. Extreme cold and famine are the obvious ones, but hibernation also has the power to combat conditions that plague modern humans, including Alzheimer’s disease, stroke and heart attack. It could even hold the key to longevity and colonising space. No wonder some researchers are keen to reinstate what might have been our long-lost superpower.

The idea that ancient humans could hibernate may seem far-fetched, but mounting evidence suggests that many non-hibernating mammals retain an ability to enter reduced-energy states, including through dormant brain-signaling pathways that slow metabolism. “The distribution of hibernating species on the tree of mammals makes the likely conclusion that the common ancestor of all mammals was a hibernator,” says Sandy Martin at the University of Colorado. “It’s possible we all have the genetic hardware.”

What is Kleine-Levin syndrome?
Kleine-Levin syndrome (KLS), also known as “sleeping beauty syndrome” or “familial hibernation syndrome,” is an extremely rare condition that causes intermittent episodes where you sleep for long periods of time, which prevents you from staying awake during the day (hypersomnia). KLS also affects your behavior. People diagnosed with KLS often sleep for 16 to 20 hours per day during a KLS episode.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57046783
Some patients with Kleine-Levin Syndrome become radically disinhibited, developing a voracious appetite for food known as hyperphagia. Two-thirds eat more – compulsively so, even stealing food or searching for it in dustbins. One drank several bottles of blackberry syrup each day. Another reported: “I would eat four or five peanut butter and jelly sandwiches – without even chewing – very fast, then would start to fall asleep again with food still in my mouth.” Unsurprisingly rapid weight gain is a feature of KLS (an average of 4.6kg per episode, but even up to 13.5kg in some). Disinhibition can also declare itself through hypersexuality. Some masturbate in public (“to the point of bleeding”, said one), expose themselves, or make unwanted sexual advances.

Fellow mall security officer here. Last year I made the decision to trust my life on the street to Second Chance body armor. I got the level IIa because it stops the most rounds. plus I got the Trauma Plate for the front.

What scares me is that, although I can fit an extra trauma plate in the front, I cannot fit a second one in back. As of late I have taken to duct-taping a second trauma plate to the area of my back where the heart and vital organs are located. Then I put my vest on.

Here is the questions. The ducttape solution, although tactically sound, is hot and painful to remove. I would like to go to the single-plate solution in back. What I am worried about is repeated hits to that area with .308 ammunition. I have a high-risk security job and I fear that I would be the target for repeated long-distance shots to my back.

Are any of you aware of a thicker plate that could stop, say, .338 Lapua or something like that? Is there a better way to do the second plate?

BTW, I am, of course, usually carrying a pair of ceramic plates in my briefcase so that I can shield my head. My SO (we work as a team when necessary) has a similar accessory containing a breakdown NEF single-shot 300 WinMag with an 18″ bbl. The plan is that I shield us with my body and “catch the rounds” while she assembles the NEF. I lay down covering fire with my 23 (Bar-Sto .357 Sig barrel) and she makes the long shots. I will then throw smoke grenades to obscure the area while continuing to lay covering fire. The problem, of course, is when I have to turn my back to run, and then the problem crops up.

>>57046238
77 grain implies you want to use the 77 grain tmk or smk projectile. neither is good for maximum lethal effect. your mk18 will be fine with any dedicated expansive ammunition meant for hunting and defense. good example would be black hills 50 grain tsx. 62 or 69 or 75 grain speer gold dot, Hornady tap and federal bonded. 77s are match bullets and are designed to comply with the Hague convention

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57046276
Elaborate but also my questioning was purely about maximizing the effective range of a shorty. Not really interested in muh expanding, because that won't matter much beyond 300 meters, because velocity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57046302
the hague convention was from the end of the 19th century/beginning of the 20th century and was a treaty signed by almost everyone limiting the type of munitions that could be used in mutual war to prevent egregious wounding or something. basically it prohibited expanding projectiles and is the reason all military ammo is mostly just fmj ball ammo. the 77 grain smk and tmk used in mk262 ammo is high end target ammo, very good ammunition and a very good projectile but they're designed with these thin target jackets that are very uniform and consistent but not good at all for shooting living things. they basically just disintegrate. the us military uses this ammo because they were able to argue these projectiles being target rounds don't expand and don't have increased lethality on target which is true, but it also means it's less then ideal if you need to shoot an animal or person regardless of range. the ammo i recommended is designed for just that.

in regards to just plinking? sure, mk262 and it's copycats is ideal. it'll be a lot easier then m193 or m855 for hitting targets.

>The Spartan hoplites cried foul. The mightiest warriors in ancient Greece had been brought low by the despised bow, a weapon they had traditionally viewed as the preserve of cowards and women. >>57025938
I'm not sure about ancient times, as it's not my main focus of interest but crossbows were extremely prolific during the high and late medieval times. There are inventory lists of small castles that would be manned by just a couple dozen men at best containing hundreds of crossbows and tens of thousands of bolts.
You see crossbows being used with great effect by many European armies of the time. From some notable examples in history, Richard 1st of England, more commonly known as Richard The Lionheart was a great proponent of usage of crossbows. During the battle of Arsuf Muslim sources explicitly state that where Christians were nearly impervious to their composite bows, continuing fighting with arrows sticking out of their backs, where the crossbows killed men and horses on the spot.
Richard also died to a crossbow bolt, but before he died from his wounds he reportedly pardoned the shooter because he thought it was a nice shot.
During later period in Eastern Europe, particularly 15th century Poland and Bohemia, crossbows were used very commonly and with great effect even when first firearms started to enter the field.
During the 1410 battle at Grunwald Poles used mounted crossbowmen in conjunction with heavy cavalry, having the mounted crossbowmen ride behind the knights on charges and firing crossbows over their heads to make sure the Teutonic Order troops were unable to properly brace against an incoming charge.

>I'm not sure about ancient times, as it's not my main focus of interest but crossbows were extremely prolific during the high and late medieval times. There are inventory lists of small castles that would be manned by just a couple dozen men at best containing hundreds of crossbows and tens of thousands of bolts.

Crossbows in Europe were rarely deployed in significant numbers, because they were very expensive and the average European prince could not afford to buy them in large quantities. The only part of Europe that could make them in mass quantities were the wealthy Northern Italian city states such as Genoa and Venice.

The only time we saw an uptick in their use in Europe was towards the end of the Late Middle Ages, but that was due to an increase in the material wealth of the region and the average soldier could now afford decent equipment.

Economics and logistics, mostly. Torsion engines were expensive to build and maintain, difficult to transport, and the best torsion batteries (made from horsehair) did *not* like to get wet, or even damp.

Pre-gunpowder field artillery just really wasn't a thing (yes, there were exceptions, but they were just that--exceptions). Artillery was something you built on-site during a siege. It's kind of a pity, because looking back on it, we are well aware today of the massive impact that field artillery has had on decisive battles in recent centuries. For the most part, however, trying to apply our modern preconceptions onto ancient battlefields just doesn't quite work out. Real history doesn't match up with Conan, much less D&D.

>>57039933
Or just use a standard heuristics.

1) population of the state/empire
2) # of armies fielded across various campaigns
3) recruiting process

1) both Roman/Han has similar population levels
2) Chinese armies are often 5-10X that of Roman empire, which could be attributed to either falsification or
3) recruiting differences can explain the difference easily
4) types of threats they have to deal with

But really, imo both Roman numbers and Chinese numbers are fairly accurate. Romans could send few legions to deal with Hannibal and they could fight and sacrifice 200-300K men fighting with the Carthage wars. Nominal it would take them decades to train a single unit of legion, so we know their recruiting process is long and daunting and ~80-100K is probably their ideal size for the Roman empire. During carthage, the situation was dire, so they had to pull conscripts to do so. Later on in Roman empire, they transitioned to keeping/maintaining an auxillairy army pulled from mercenary corps and outer Roman empire.
For the Han/Qin Chinese, they could field ~300-400K units effectively because they still retained the older feudal kingdom militaries that were defined by total war grindset. Every able bodied men were conscripted in the empire, barring some special exemptions. And they were required to undergo 2-3 years of minimum training. Hence the pool of military recruits were much larger, as well as the efficiency. On top of that, the career military size was usually ~1/3 of the total size. So technically, Chinese had similar standing army size as Roman in nominal times, maybe 2-3x larger, but not 5-10x. Its only when dealing with threats, that the Chinese were able to spool up recruitments as they were already pre-trained.

Nominal it would take them decades to train a single unit of legion, so we know their recruiting process is long and daunting and ~80-100K is probably their ideal size for the Roman empire. During carthage, the situation was dire, so they had to pull conscripts to do so. Later on in Roman empire, they transitioned to keeping/maintaining an auxillairy army pulled from mercenary corps and outer Roman empire.

The big myth about the Roman Legion is that they were a predominantly professional force; an image that doesn't hold up with more recent scholarship. The Roman military was not all that different from their contemporaries; a small corps of professionals supported by mercenaries during peacetime and supplemented by mass conscription during wartime. This was the standard practice for the Roman state and it never stopped even towards the end of the Empire.

> Its only when dealing with threats, that the Chinese were able to spool up recruitments as they were already pre-trained.

The Chinese did have a sophisticated reserve system, but it was both an asset and liability to the ruling dynasties. When shit got bad and there were local rebellions, they were a serious threat to the government because the rebels often had some sort of paramilitary training and familiarity with the force and command structure of the government armies

The old state politics revolved around confucian politicians from various parts of China forming majority of the rules and emperors taking a more imperial role. But with the Ming, they centralized the power into an absolute monarch system. The confucian politicians were put aside and the imperial enuchs were the ones making the laws. This corrupted the system greatly (although the old system was almost as corrupt). Leading to monarch dissatisfactions and eventual political betrayals by local politicians in favor of Qing dynasty. The disheavel was worse in Qing because they weren't "Chinese" proper either. Like the Mongols of the past, they were viewed as outsiders and needed to be overthrown/etc. Qing had to wrestle with countless insurgencies throughout the empire as political instability led to their collapse. But even as the political system was on the brink of collapse, their tech/mettalurgy industries never wavered. In fact, more and more guns were used in all walks of life in Chinese military. So the premise is flawed.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>57046968
Follow up to >>57047745. I looked in more detail They itemize in the listings. Looks like gun + optic prices are pretty much market. The secret sauce is where they upcharge for the ammo, accessories, and custom work and then add on a premium for putting together the ensemble. For instance, who buys $300 holsters and magnaports everything? The markup isn't as crazy as I thought, but were the gun to come in a minimal configuration nobody could stomach shelling out for the most expensive light, the most expensive holster, the most expensive optic, etc unless they're getting a killer deal. I guess if you're a rich boomer and the worst thing you can imagine doing is thinking through something on your own, this would be the kind of thing you would do, because they're selling the most expensive version of everything you could possibly consider buying for the gun along with the gun.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Good /k/ books or interesting parts from them.

I will post a few of my older ones. First is the memoir of a British soldier under Kitchener from August, 1914 to the Battle of Loos in September l, 1915. It was published in early 1916, so it was still subject to censorship.

It's a funny book. Sort of a non-fiction Catch-22. I'll post a particularly funny part about how the soldiers essentially all they can to avoid having to fight each other in real combat and how much they hate people with heavy weapons who get fire directed on them.

Interestingly, "Kraut," "Jerry," "Hun," etc. don't really appear here. The Germans are "Borches" or "Teutons."

I normally find these a flea markets. Most books 100-200 years old have been kept for their fancy covers so there are a ton of Bibles, collected works you can find in print anywhere, history tomes, etc. I find the interesting stuff is rarer, the less popular military and diplomatic memoirs, or travel books. Also science books are kind of neat. I almost got an 1860 science textbook the other day but nabbed a first edition report of Perry's mission to Japan instead.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57023967
5.7 doesn't have an appropriate diameter to expand reliably, hollowpoints only expand 1/5th of the time and the one that does still has very poor expansion. You're entirely relying on fragmentation or tumbling to occur to get a bigger wound channel than a .22 hole. If you know your ballistic shit, you know all the planets have to align for tumbling and fragmentation to happen. I'd say those are unreliable wounding mechanisms too. Ultimately, 5.7 lacks the mass to penetrate light barriers like windshields and car doors without excessive deflection. It will never be adopted as a police duty round for those reasons.

.40 did what it was designed to do, which was be 10-15% better than 9mm. It still is, because modern powder advancements improved .40 loads too. 9mm now consistently makes the minimum penetration requirements, but the one thing .40 still has a leg up on is light barrier penetration. It will go through something like a windshield or car door with less deflection than 9mm. The police agencies may not have made the right decision to drop it, but I wouldn't invest in it because it won't be a common round in the future. Just get a 10mm if you want something that blows 9 the fuck out of the water. There's a lot of badass versatile loads you can get in 10mm that you can't get with boring cope rounds like .40 or .357. 9mm is just a good all around, very common round. A must have but not a beast by any means, leaves a little to be desired.

>>57033865
I wouldn't trust it as an all around handgun calibers until I see testing on that. I haven't, I'm just assuming. That's where these light .20 cal rounds don't perform well. Even rifle .20 caps like 5.56 can deflect from twigs being in the bullet path, and they struggle with any sort of barrier penetration at range. There are verified reports from the sandbox that it bounces off car windshields in firefights at extended ranges.

This would be a good thing to suggest a reviewer to test out. It's a promising round but it's a tiny little baby, I don't anticipate it doing well. Ammo manufacturers also need to revisit 5.7 loadings because they don't have adequate ballistics gel penetration depth. They typically stop just short of 12"

>The roots of at least some of Tornado’s problems lie in a lack of compromise from the British side and the interference of political considerations. As the former West German Chief of Air Staff Heinz Birkenbeil noted in Dr Alfred Price’s ‘Panavia Tornado‘, “Before we went into the programme the German requirement was for a daylight attack plane. All the other European nations and Canada needed a replacement for the F-104, each nation put in its requirements and the requirements were a long way apart. In the second round the British required a deep interdiction aircraft with at least twice as much range as the Germans wanted, and all at low level for strike and conventional attack –– we had wanted an aeroplane for strike and close air support, with an air superiority capability over the battlefield. But we had not been after an aeroplane for deep interdiction… I told our Chief of Air Staff [General Steinhoff] that my department did not think the projected aircraft would fit the german requirement. And then a funny thing happened. The programme was of great political importance to Europe and the politicians stepped in…The result of this in Germany was the Chief of Air Staff simply changed our Air Force’s requirement until it eventually fitted the requirement of the MRCA!”

posts.name: Anonymous

>>57031776
NTA, but Virginia-class boats only have 12x VLS cells for tomahawks. Whereas the UK's Astute-class boats have UP to 36 tomahawks, though realistically they split their loadout between tomahawks and torpedos likely favouring torpedos since the UK isn't about using their SSNs for land attack. I believe most Astute-class boats would have 12 tomahawks and 24 torpedos to match a standard US Virginia-class boat armament. But theoretically, an Astute-class boat on a specific land-attack mission could be loaded up with purely tomahawks and have more than a Virginia-class boat.

The Block V Virginia-class adds the VPM which increases the VLS cells to 40 (28 VLS cells in the VPM + 12 in the standard VLS cells) plus the standard torpedo loadout on top of that, which takes it beyond the Astute-class in land-attack potential. But as of right now, no Block V boats are in service (2027?) yet.


tldr; he's technically correct but also kinda wrong based on actual deployment use.

>>57041704
battery and capacitor tech needs to improve greatly. as a species, we get magnetism pretty well, and we get electronics ok. power storage is still a tough nut to crack. at the end of the day, it's a whole lot easier to put flammable shit in a can and set it on fire (standard cartridges) than it is to round up the sparky bois and put those in a can (capacitors). or, worse yet, put shit in a can that does shit to make sparky bois at a slow rate (batteries). the best we have is lipo batteries for most applications, and those are picky as fuck to use and very easy to destroy through normal usage. the grunt factor comes into play here, and the end result is an underpowered weapon with expensive projectiles that the newly recruited Pvt. Parts won't be able to fix or maintain. you would also be giving suicide sticks to armorers who don't understand electronics, as the capacitors involved would likely be enough to kill 5 guys at the same time if it shorted out on someone. even house appliance capacitors can easily harm or kill you if you're grounded the right way. imagine what a weapons-grade magnetic rail driver could do, and would have to do in order to make the weapon work.

all this being said, am i shitting on the idea in its entirety? no, absolutely not. when battery and capacitor tech gets to where it needs to be, you would have a functionally silent weapon that could be recharged on the fly, and in its advanced form could hopefully rely on purely ferrous ammo instead of rare earth ammo. the result would be fantastically cheap to operate compared to pricey brass and volatile gunpowder, although we've gotten extremely good at cheapening those.

don't expect them in your lifetime, but expect them in your grandkid's lifetime.

>>57042356
Well, let me make a list.
-Effectively suppressed. There's no exploding powder so there's no flash or report. This does wonders for the user's hearing and sight.
-Caseless. No powder, no casings. No issues that you'd need casings to sort out.
-Variable muzzle velocity. Turn it down for a more controllable close quarters weapon or turn it up for a longer range weapon. Add a range finder and you've got a riot shotgun that works at all ranges.
-Variable ammunition. You don't use expanding gas from burning propellant so you don't need an airtight seal in the barrel. This gives you a lot more options in what you're shooting. You could even load HESH or even HEAT rounds if the barrel is wide enough. Hell, you could shove steel ball bearings in the chamber if you run out of real ammo.
-Regenerative recoil absorption. Basically regenerative breaking and not so much a benefit as a necessity. The user will feel less recoil when shooting and the capacitors will get a partial recharge after every shot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57043088
>Just use a suppressor, then. It is not like those are some sort of black budget tech
Suppressors overheat and wear out quickly. They're also not as effective as not having anything to suppress to begin with.
>There were already several successful attempts at making caseless firearms using chemical propellants
That's because they were chemical propellant guns. Coilguns don't use chemical propellants so you don't need air tight seals, ad hoc heat sinks, container for the lions share of the fouling, etc.
>Useless 99% of the time, and in the 1% of the times it could be useful just using some low-velocity ammo suffice
There was quite a few times in Iraq and Afghanistan where US troops were being sniped from outside M16 range and quite a few times those same troops needed to do room clearings. Low velocity doesn't mean low recoil. Usually, it means a heavier round because dropping the chamber pressure too much will cause the gun to misfeed.
>Normal guns already have different ammo types,
Normal guns need the round to be flush with the barrel. You need an airtight seal or the gas will leak out. Coilguns don't care about how the round fits in the barrel outside of how straight the bullet flies. In fact, you can go pure smoothbore because you don't get that tailwind destabilizing fin stabilized rounds.
>ost modern firearms already use some sort of recoil absorption technique. Again, a non-issue.
Actually, it's somewhat rare to have recoil absorption besides a stock. Most guns are gas operated if only because of Kalashnikov and those actions are locked until the bullet leaves the gun. There are muzzle brakes that can compensate for recoil but if you use a muzzle brake you can't use a suppressor.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57029313
Owing to your picture of big hunting revolvers there, it's because it's a LOT cheaper to make a high powered repeating handgun such as a revolver, especially on existing tooling and going on existing designs, than it is to develop and produce a proper automatic pistol.

The Desert Eagle is designed around mostly rimmed revolver cartridges, but it's a picky bitch when it comes to what kind of ammo it likes, and it only tolerates perfect shooting stance. The Coonan and Grizzly are probably the most practical Magnum autos ever, but they're expensive, and the latter hasn't been in production for many years, tragically, we're also up into Coonan's second revival.
The Wildey has certain adaptability, but is also expensive, and is built around rimless Magnum handgun cartridges which aren't widely available. The AMC Auto Mag has had promise, but it has been handled awfully for most of its history, and there's a lot of problems, maybe the revamped ones have this solved and it'll have a better shot, we'll see, but just the same it calls for less common rimless ammunition. The AMT Automag (which is different) is vaguely like the Grizzly if it was retarded.

Beyond that, revolvers have this appeal to reliability, with how they don't depend on the power of your cartridge to cycle (outside of rare exceptions), and that they're very simple to handle. We can argue just how truthful or relevant this reliability part really is, particularly with how even cheap ammo these days is lightyears ahead of cheap ammo from over a century ago, or how revolver lockworks have all these big openings for hypothetical dirt to get in.
Most people don't live in a WW1 trench though, and they don't shoot mysterious unlabeled ammo they found under the fridge when they moved in, so typically their revolvers don't struggle to function. The modest (centerfire) snubbie revolver has a record of being adequate for defense 999 times out of 1000, so it's not going away any time soon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57029516
>Revolvers are still the best for home defense
They certainly work, and most likely it's gonna cut it, but 6 or 7 shots of .38 Special, while usable, isn't really better than 17 shots of 9mm Luger, not to talk about a shotgun with No. 4 buckshot.
There's Magnum revolvers of course, but they are VERY loud, and if you're going to go for a powerful gun which is really loud, I want to suggest some sort of rifle and carbine instead.

>doesnt put any wear on springs
Springs wear from active compression and decompression, they don't wear when static, ergo when relaxed or when under pressure, that's thermodynamics. HOWEVER, there are some things to note, that with certain magazines, keeping those loaded has the potential of causing say, the feed lips to subtly and slowly deform from spring pressure over a long period of time, typically plastic ones of lower quality, but I've heard one or two anecdotes of Hi-Point magazines doing that.

>no worries about malfunctions
Kept in the hospitable conditions of a bedside drawer, I should expect any half decent handgun to manage that just fine, especially if you do clean it after taking it out for practice.

This isn't directly relevant to the bedside drawer example, but if you drop the average double-action hand-ejector revolver in muddy and sandy water, that's extremely likely to make the lockwork seize up, while something like a Glock 17 is very likely to manage that with few, if any malfunctions at all. The main advantage a revolver has for reliability is that it doesn't use the power of a cartridge to cycle, so it can be operated like normal with any underloaded ammo or even duds, but this is less big of a point where even pretty cheap ammo very rarely have those problems.
This isn't 1896, it's very easy to find consistently decent ammo for a decent price.

posts.com:
Revolvers have advantages on the large end of handguns and the small end. Large hunting revolvers can handle large loads for game during handgun season and offer easy optic mounting solutions. Small revolvers can compete with the size, weight, and capacity of small semis, and don't suffer from the downsides of high spring weights, small slides, and limp wristing/grip issues. They also draw better as tiny guns and have more curved surfaces. And if you go down to .22lr/mag you won't have to worry about primers and case rims as much.

For the K to L frame revolvers it starts to not make sense, you can carry a mid size 9mm and have way more capacity for the weight and size. 6 shots of .357 in a +33oz gun vs 16 shots of 9mm in a 30oz(or less) gun of a similar footprint... the revolver only has niche benefits at that point.

Revolvers exist in several neich markets.
A. The cheapest gun at the lowest end of capacity.
They feed .22 reliably, cost very little to produce, you might take one as a tool for shooting varmints or if you're a 12 year old looking to execute a 15 year old.
B. Alternating between exotic cartridges.
Some won't feed or cycle, this naturally feeds into A. Because you might concievable have two rounds of .38, two rounds of snake shot, a blank and a slug. If you were actually a rancher.
C. Hunting revolvers
You're shooting large animals, you need a large calibre, you can't carry two large guns. You won't get the opportunity to reload anyway, you're in a situation where you genuinely couldn't survive a jam, the action is easier to clean.
D. Disposable murder weapons
You would rather a semi auto, but are throwing away a gun per week and can't justify the expense. The contract killing market is pretty thin so your margins can't take too many hits.
E. You can't get your head around a semi auto, somthing /k/ sort of takes for granted. You would remove the mag but forget the chambered round, you can't rack the slide with your lard hands, you pull the mag outv by accident, you can't count rounds unless you're looking at them, when you clean your gun (when it stops working) the springs fly out and you can't get them back in.
Sur you bedder get a reevolver gun
F. D. But the government pays you. Komrade the makarov is good gun, mate the webley works fine.

posts.name: Burt
posts.com:
I hope somebody here snaps one or both of these up, man these are cool. Both quite rare guns though only a little weird.

The Sirkis is an early version of what would later be called the Sardius SD9 whose only virtue is you've probably never heard of it lol. The Tressitu is a South African (TZ99) copy of the Israeli copy (Golan) of the Yugoslavian copy (CZ99) of the P226/P88. Mechanically not super interesting as these lack the CZ99's "3 round hand poke indicator" but this one is factory hard chromed which is very rare. I had been looking for one of these for about 10 years with zero results until I stumbled on to a CZ99 to fill this niche.

https://handgunsoftheworld.com/product/sirkis-industries-sirkis-sd9-9mm-with-case/

https://handgunsoftheworld.com/product/tressitu-mitchell-double-action-9mm-with-case/

He's also got a Mamba, a CZ 100, a Detonics Pocket 9, an FMK 9C1 Bill of Rights Edition and a Dardick 1500 (!) for sale but I think they're all way overpriced.

posts.com: My astigmatism doesn't seem to effect the usage of pistol dots as much as I had thought. I bought a steiner mps and it only smears downwards. This results in the 3.3 moa dot smearing to become a little less than a 6 moa dot. It still seems very useful at 50-100y. Sometimes I can see two dots, but the fake one is always less bright and below the actual dot. The dot is much less likely to "double" or smear if I leave it on lower brightness settings. I will probably go to an eye doctor and get this checked out because prior to using optics I didn't know I had any vision problems, but I still find them useful. Also, my eotech 512 has almost no issues with my astigmatism. I know it's not the dot but my eyesight because my left eye can see the dot fine, but unfortunately I'm right eye dominant.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57037414
Circle dot reticles tend to seem to be affected less because the larger reticle helps you pick up the dot at lower brightness settings. The lower the brightness, the less blur.

as for pistol dot sizes, competition shooters almost exclusively favor 8 moa dots or better. When you think about it an 8 moa dot is a 2 inch group at 25yards. Big dot helps you pick it up and track it quicker, and a smaller dot seems to “wiggle” more. Take the big dot pill anon

posts.name: Burt
posts.com:
>>57040626
9mm is far and away the most common centerfire pistol caliber, though I don't have numbers to quantify that.

I guess you could get a .40 pistol, a small number of which can accept 9mm barrels with no further modification and have a pistol that shoots 2 calibers. And .40 and .357 barrels are directly interchangeable in virtually all pistols of either of those two calibers. But this would not apply for .45 or .22 or any other caliber. And now you're looking at +$200 for each caliber, getting rarer and rarer to encounter in this fantasy scenario where you still would encounter a bunch more 9mm or .22

This is all theorycrafting fantasy though. The ammo you have is going to be the ammo you bring with you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57041718
It’s the PMM comp, I can feel it barely able to cycle with it with a stock spring. The ejection pattern is very weak too. The Jarvis uses a set screw which is superior to just globs of threadlocker the PMM comp uses. With 115 gr the muzzle barely moves, probably because I also have a x300 on it. If you want the ability to use 115 gr light loads on stock springs you want to get the Jarvis single port comp, not the double port.

I do not recommend the PMM if you care about finish, it’s poor. mine also requires a fat stack (two shim kits from them) to be clocked properly and not impede the slide.

>>57042762
No. About four years ago, if you had polled people as to what mount pattern would win the format war, people would have said the DPP pattern. Nowadays it's quite deprecated. The only optic that's been released for the DPP in the past few years has been the EFLX, because EOTech are an ancient company of boomers who don't know what they're doing. The Sig optics that fit the DPP were only released because they were originally for their own proprietary mount pattern, and nobody bought them, so Sig caved and released the Pro series of optics that fit the DPP. Still, nobody buys them except for Sig diehards.

If you polled people a year or two ago, they might suppose that the RMR pattern is going to "win", but it's still very much up in the air. The only future-proofing solution is plates, at least until a pattern actually takes over, which might never happen.

I recognize those Turkish shotguns, I don't remember the model but some Russian gun dealer had a video where he brought out like 40 brand new ones to a shooting range and almost all permajammed on the first shot, often shedding broken internal parts and basically being ridiculously unsafe.

Little background info, Turkey has strict gun laws with an exception for shotguns, so they make a metric shitton of shotguns there for domestic sale, especially tactical types that mimic ARs, bullpups, and so forth. Apparently a fair number of their smaller manufacturers dump QC failures and outright failed designs on the US market, often through shady fly-by-night import/export resellers that are impossible to get warranty repair or even returns through. Because of this, consumers and FFLs are left holding the bag on something that's not even airsoft quality, with no way to get them fixed or even return them.

This is why people shit on the majority of Turkish shotguns, or at least those not made by Stoeger or another Beretta subsidiary. It isn't just the quality control, it's also getting any warranty service worth a damn out of any Turkish factory not owned by Italians in some way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57046601
>cannot be in the optimum position for RCS and control at all times
I think what he means is that if a J-20 were to maneuver and it's control surfaces (in this case canards) move to accommodate that, that movement depending on the angle would potentially show more of a flat surface to radar, therefore increasing the return.
Like if you see a fighter front the front, the vertical stabilizer is tougher to see because it's thin and directly in front of you. If you see it front the side the vertical stabs are now showing much more. Which is typically why stealth fighters have larger side returns, and subsequently why shit like the B-2 and B-21/NGAD whatever don't/won't have them at all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57046619
On a conventional layout, the main wings (much larger than tailplanes or canards) are on the front instead, so does that not affect negatively on RCS?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57046818
The main wings don't tilt and show more of themselves the way a canard does anon. from the front the leading edge of the wings is fairly flat, where as the canard would move and tilt and expose more surface.
Even if you were looking at the thing from the top or bottom, where the main wings are much larger, the canards STILL add additional surface area to reflect a return.
It affects the RCS, the Chinese likely came to the conclusion that it's worth the tradeoffs, but having extra surfaces always will effect RCS. It's why tailless designs are considered the stealthiest option

>>57046420
>I also believe the Germans used BC's for commerce raiding in both world wars.
They didn't in WW1; just used them for a couple hit-and-run coastal raids to try and provoke a British response which they could then pounce on with the whole High Seas Fleet. It never worked because the British had cracked their signals codes and knew what the Germans were up to. Commerce raiding with large warships would have been suicide for those ships given the vastly superior Allied naval forces. Stealth, subterfuge, and guile kept German commerce raiders alive, not speed and size.

In WW2 Germany did not have any battlecruisers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: A ship intended to participate in both line of battle fleet actions and commerce raiding/defense. It a fast battleship's "stats" are 100 speed/100 armor/100 guns, a battlecruiser has 100 speed and 150 distributed into the other two. You get some ships like the British battlecruisers that are glass cannons, you get some like the Japanese/German battlecruisers that are more like second rate battleships.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Previous >>56962567
Old Cover New Thread
Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

>>57028867
Tested the arc bridge last night, did a short sprint just to see if it will hold up from the position I set it to and it held up fine so far.
I decided to allow the bridge to do the widest FOV as it was very manageable to get the pano view to merge in my brain and man in it really is a nice feature to have when you are navigating, looking from a standard 40 degree bino setup at a few houses from the park roughly 50-75yds away I was seeing 3 houses and switching to pano FOV it allowed me to see about 2 houses extra to the left and right side, the blending of the two tubes is like looking at a venn diagram and it does take some time to get used to it for me it took about 10-20 seconds to adjust a bit of the arms to get the right position to allow me to get used to the merging of the images after that I was able to walk around like I normally can with mono or standard bino configurations.
I vastly prefer three arc bridge over the panobridge, it was simple to just pull apart the arms to get into pano view vs the panobridge requiring to get the right angle for both arms and it basically giving you unlimited adjustments it was harder to get the right placement and also it loosens over time quickly so you have to readjust quite often.
Using the Jerry-C/COTI was interesting, in the standard bino confusion the thermal overlay looked similar to how it looked in a mono confusion meaning my brain merged the two images. Once I set the pano FOV the thermal tube and non thermal tube split the display and my brain was able to tell the two tube display apart.
Unfortunately my NVGR recorder didn't record any video footage and I don't know why, I took out the sd card to see if there's any new video files and maybe the old video files that were already on there from a prior recording session caused it to not record as files existed already, but I deleted those files and did a simple test and the camera did record in that test, so I dunno.

Assuming that the combined nuclear arsenals of the world were targeted at each other to maximize casualties (something that would never happen because nukes are intended to target enemy nuclear launch sites, which are very far away from population centers, first and infrastructure, military targets, and government facilties second) you would be extremely lucky to get 2 billion kills (assuming one of those nukes targets the Three Gorges Dam and successfully drowns 600 million Chinese). >>57045472
Radiation is a minimal- to non-concern for modern nuclear weapons, which are expressly designed to minimize radioactive fallout through air-burst to maximize the concussive blast and heat wave (not to be confused with the fireball) which causes the greatest amount of damage. Radioactive fallout is a result of the nuclear fireball from the explosion coming into contact with soil and launching it into the atmosphere; the radius of gamma-burst radiation through the air from a modern nuclear detonation varies between about 90-300 meters, and if you're under a thousand feet away from a nuclear bomb exploding, radiation is going to be the least of your concerns.

Keep in mind, the above-ground testing of Nuclear bombs at Los Alamos and elsewhere DID explode right next to the earth and launched tons of radioactive particulate into the atmosphere as some of the dirtiest nuclear detonations ever committed, on American soil, within a few hundred miles of millions of Americans. And yet, somehow, America and Americans still exist, and have not all died out from radioactive fallout.

So thinking this through practically.

Russian Nukes are not known for their accuracy (they can be km off target) and given they haven't been testing the launch vehicles regularily as far as anyone in the west knows, it's likely given how poorly maintained their USSR Stock is that a not insignificant double digit percentage will fail, not to mention the west has AEGIS and The starwars program stuff in LEO. In an all out exchange Russia needs a lot more nukes than the US has due to those failures and defenses as a deterrent. The US Stockpile on the other hand is accurate, plentiful, largely mobile (half of them are on Ohio Class Nuclear Subs), and has sufficient volume to keep the enemy down permanently once put down. If the Russians decided to do an all-out nuking of the US, it would absolutely be the permanent end of Russia. The main purpose of the Stockpile is to prevent invasion or aggression, e.g. if overzealous US Generals or Europeans decide to Nuke Russia ahead of time which is an absolutely valid fear IMO.

Furthermore, the US has AGM-130 and GBU-72 bunker buster bombs. You have to assume producing a variant that can be put into orbit with rapidly developed rockets e.g. what SpaceX does, manuvered into positions over Silo's, Submarine bases, and Launchers, then dropped on target with high accuracy is doable, especially considering the design to deployment was done in weeks. That would give the US the capibility to knock out their command and control, silo's, submarine docks, and anti-air missile defense systems opening the mobile launchers for attack by air. You destroy most or all of that capibility, China, the Middle East and Europe invades or uses nukes to finish them off. It would be a very shitty engagement for all parties however, given the weather impact...

Answering this.
Under "ideal" detonating conditions a nuclear warhead will produce radioactive isotopes. Meaning you take some asphault, concrete, heat it up to 10,000C, shove tons of neutrons into it, then blow it into the stratosphere and yeah, it's going to be radioactive, the atoms are going to absorb the neutrons and destabilize, and the material is going to break down into something else over time. Most of these isotopes are short-lived ergo the law of 7's.

> 7 hours = 90% reduction in radiation
> 7 days = 99% reduction
> 7 months = 99.9% reduction
> 7 years = 99.99% reduction

In an all out exchange you are putting probably thousands of tons of radioactive sut into the atmosphere so when it rains, it's all going to come down. So keep in mind here in an all-out scenario, you probably need to sit underground for a year.

However, again, the Russian Nuclear stockpile is likely not that reliable and or accurate. What happens when a dud warhead slams into something really flammible such as an oil refinery or highrise? The radioactive metal will burn, combine with whatever is onsite, and flow through the air downwind as a fine dust coating crap for hundreds or thousands of feet downwind. Look at the recent east palestine, ohio train derailment as a case study in how this can play out.

Imagine downtown Chicago or New York got hit. You could force the evacuation of long island for example and displace millions with a subcritical detonatio. Plutonium has about a decades-long half-life, Uranium's is something like 80 years. Absolutely possible to pelt an area with defective nukes and make it totally uninhabitable for a century or three. Imagine that happening to Washington DC, Hoover Dam, Mountain passes in the rockies, Major Locke's and Ports, nuclear plants. It would allow you to modify the way geography works to really fuck over the local population without needing to shoot shit into the stratosphere.

Doing a New Vegas run with a sniper/shotgun build, with STR 7 and LK 8. At level 14, I have Finesse, Shotgun Surgeon, and And Stay Back, Stealth 85, Guns 85, a modded hunting rifle (can't remember how you get Paciencia) , a riot shotgun, .22 Submachine gun, and Ratslayer, and I'm wearing Vault 34 security armor (better DT than combat armor while being light) and Combat Helm Mk 2.

I never realized how fucking broken shotguns are in NV. Riot shotgun loaded with flechettes along with the above perks means you're essentially untouchable in close range combat and can merk Centurions in seconds, and 4/0 Buck is awesome against creatures. After I decimate the legion I'll figure out how this build does against NCR rangers given that they're much better in long range combat, but so far I haven't found an NPC in the game that can survive a .308 AP sneak critical to the head, especially after you take Better Criticals. And I've also been wanting to try if Pulse Slugs are effective against Brotherhood Paladins.

Question for NV veterans, what's the point of Dragon's Breath and beanbag rounds? It looks like DB gives some fire damage but does slightly less direct damage, while Beanbag rounds are a nonlethal option to knock down NPCs. What's the point?

It's a mini screwdriver used to very small screws like on glasses.

You pull it out of the corkscrew, turn it around and fasten it back on "upside down", and you can use it to screw/unscrew very small things. It's put there inside the corkscrew just to save space. This was the corkscrew functions both as a storage space adn a fitting on which it is attached to.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57046581
>>57046610
Officially, the hook in a Swiss Army Knife is meant for carrying parcels or packages wrapped with string or thin cords, that can be hung from the hook and carried along with the body of the SAK acting as a handle. This is the reason it is sometimes referred to as the parcel hook. The hook is quite sturdy, and Victorinox says it is strong enough to carry loads as heavy as 200 lbs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57042066
A traditional sling in practiced hands is much more powerful than any rubber sling, even some super Joerg Sprave deal, provided there's no mechanical pulling device. The sling at it's peak of training with good ammunition was directly competitive with the strongest bows and crossbows. The strongest bows took years to build up the strength to use, and the strongest crossbows required winches to pull back.


Joerg here generally makes his slingshots much more powerful than any commercial model, and you can see while the impacts would be extremely painful and maybe even require the hospital, even at close range they're not going to penetrate very deeply. That said, a slingshot style weapon can be useful to hunt with or as a harassing weapon against a poorly armed enemy if you cant access anything better.

https://youtu.be/IBhCQLLTSHk

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57042308
>absolutely, any sane person would. that being said, some people don't have ready access to decent hunting arms
Have you even attempted to get a legal firearm where you are? Sure it might be a tyrannical and unreasonable process but if you haven't even tried it how are you going to overcome even bigger challenges (like say, having to shoot someone to defend yourself)?
Failing a gun, there are airguns, Crossbows, and even old fashioned guns like Cap and Ball revolvers that all have different laws depending on the country.

Joerg sprave made a lot of money marketing his "Air-ringer" and "Scuba Ringer" pistols, which are two shot airguns that circumvent a lot of the airgun laws in some European countries. He also sells the Adder series of crossbows, which have a magazine holding multiple bolts and can be reloaded and fired again in only a couple of seconds. The most powerful of which, the "Siege" I think he calls it, can fire light bolts at over 400FPS, which is far more lethal than any arm powered rubber sling, and enough to punch it's projectiles all the way through someone's body.
As for making weapons on your own:
There are many tutorials on youtube for making muzzle loading firearms, Crossbows, Bows, and air guns using only materials you can find at every hardware store in the west. Even in Japan, one of the most anti gun countries on the planet, an insane man recently proved that anyone could build a musket easily, and he used one to assassinate a the former prime minister. There are tutorials on how to make arrow shooting airguns using common components that can reach speeds of 500FPS with full sized arrows, enough to kill any animal that walks the earth.

Ar-15, it's undebatable at this point. Other choices are adequate, or may be superior for some extremely narrow circumstances(much less common than people think), but the AR is the best choice the vast majority of the time. The only real competition comes from bullpups.

A myth
>Muh blast
Electronic ears, shotguns of similar size are as bad or worse, PCCs are still bad but not as bad. If you don't have time for ears then you don't have time for an off body gun.
>Muh house clearing
Short enough outside of deep corners, house clearing is retarded, house clearing with a handgun is even more so. Don't. Also handguns don't count, shotguns are worse, and PCCs are almost identically bad.
>Cost
They're cheap now, same price range as anything that isn't a hipoint or clapped out pump gun.

posts.com:
Y’all spend too much time wargaming, this thread is some eternal LARPer shit.

The correct answer is the one you have available and have trained with. Outside of that a tube/mag fed shotgun with a proper defensive load is the best bet. You have a better chance of ending a threat with a single trigger pull of a shotgun than any other firearm. It allows you to be slightly less efficient with your shot placement, not because of the pattern, but because a shotgun imparts more of its kinetic energy into the body. You do not want to get into an exchange of any form, so a weapon that allows you to be the most lethal in the least amount of time is the best bet.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57030229
>Does a balloon have a heat signature?
AIM-9X Block IIs have datalinks and extremely sensitive thermal imagers that are closer to FLIR cameras than the old AIM-9Bs or Ds used in Vietnam. Considering the outside of the satellite bus (which is basically what the sensor part of the balloon is) is connected to the inside, which would have to operate above -30C, there's more than enough heat there for the AIM-9 to lock onto.

I think commercial FLIR imagery auto adjusting for the range of heat in a scene confuses laymen as to how sensitive these systems actually are. They see a person on a cool backdrop with a perceived "small" dynamic range because of the color grading (so 30-40C max) and don't realize that the same system is probably capable of discerning a 400C object down to 0.1C resolution against a 0C backdrop.

I'm not an expert so I could be entirely off the mark here, but...

AIM-9s use IR guidance which basically locks onto the bright spot in an image. Usually the exhaust of a jet, the heat of an engine, or flares launched as countermeasures. This causes people to think they're purely heat-seeking, but they really look for contrast in the image from their camera, for example a white balloon against an empty sky. See >>57030284

>>57042083
the XM5 is still undergoing preliminary testing, and the few reports from the soldiers testing them are mixed. it's a great replacement for their 7.62mm rifles and the XM250 is way better than the M240 and M249, but the weight and lower ammo capacity than the M4/M16 seems to be a common complaint. fielding the XM5 would involve completely rewriting the training structure that soldiers go through, since it would change from "keep the enemy pinned down until artillery wipes them out" to "take them out one at a time with precision fire"
in my view, the XM5 would best serve as a replacement for the M110A1 and other DMRs. it's got the range and penetration capabilities to match and has a similar barrel life, but is a more compact package so it would work better in the even a designated marksman got into a close range encounter

>>57041567
Guns should be the last thing on your checklist
1) obtain a property with access to running water
2) build a dwelling on it preferably with a basement/bunker
3) spend some time in it learning about the area, learning bushcraft, learning what sort of wild food plants and trees grow in the area and their uses, learning what game lives in the area, how the place manages winters and what it needs to be maintained
3) learn how skin, break down, and prepare an animal you have killed
4) learn how to preserve food and home canning
5) stockpile canned food, commercial and home made
(why dont I just buy baked beans? because eventually there may not be supermarkets stocked with baked beans so learning how to do it yourself means lasting longer)
You dont need a wall of guns that is stupid and paranoid and wasteful - you cant eat it
A hunting rifle like a Remmington 700 in .308, a shotgun with a variety of different shells for different game and defense, a pistol. Maybe an assault rifle or battle rifle, but that is very optional.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>57036656
Demographics don't necessarily be destiny with AI. Already during the IT revolution we've seen a massive, shift in how all income is generated in an economy. It used to be considered a law of economics that 66% of all income came from people working and 33% came from (mostly passive) ownership of capital. We have seen that trending towards 50%. AI will only accelerate this. Truck driver is the most common occupation in many US states and those jobs will all go away and be replaced as gains to capital. Check out clerks have also declined rapidly and may vanish entirely. Even jobs that will work with AI, programmers, etc. can do more work quicker with AI assistance, while there will be less demand for their labor. This in turn means lower wages while owners get higher productivity and income.

We've already seen this with the job crisis for lawyers and paralegals. States can afford to pay defenders and DAs $40-55k because with digital search one person can do the legal research of 20 people using paper books of case law. Apps even do cognitive behavioral therapy now. AI chatbots and eventually voice will come to replace tons of customer service jobs. Gains here all accrue to owners of capital. The top 10% of the US already owns 90+% of all wealth, 90+% of all stocks and bonds, and that will only accelerate.

War fighting is rapidly becoming more automated. Automated recon and spotter drones send fire missions to automated batteries that can aim themselves. A few guys can work an automated battery instead of a large team. UGVs are also only getting better. AI can pull together data from sensors from tiny UAVs to drone dispersed seismic detectors, to persistent lighter than air drones patrolling the skies. Add in cameras being everywhere and facial recognition software, plus DNA records and surveillance becomes incredibly potent. Radicals and rebels can be detected, tracked, and eliminated by small teams using a vast network of AI and autonomous data...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57041461
Not him but,

You can disassemble the M14 style rifles all you want. The no disassembly is only for a M21 bedded stock since the glass beading can chip and loosen after every disassembly. Don't believe the fud about M14 issues, what ever they were it does not exist in a modernized M14 rifle.

FAL was objectively better in the day but not anymore. Original furniture is better in handling than M14 furniture of the same era, this is fact. Unfortunately FAL has low market appeal in todays commercial market and no one really makes good modern upgrades for it. They are adequate but not great.

M14 style rifles in the original base configuration trades blows with the FAL on different things but has since way outclassed what ever you can do with a modern FAL setup.
There is a wide range of upgrades for a M14 pattern rifles which are easily available. A modern M14 stock like, the CQB stock, can take AK grips and AR buttstocks wile adding mlock rails and qd swing swivels totally blows the FAL handling argument out of the water these days. Add to the fact that you have better optics mount options and even an ar15 style bolt release that can be added as well. Plus the M14 is also the better rifle to accurize out of the 3 NATO battle rifles. Handloading and a modern stock can get you sub MOA accuracy out of most M14 rifles fairly easily without the need to glass bead like a M21 style stock.

But of course there is no replacement for the old NATO feel of the original setups from when these rifles were in service.

posts.com: I know this isn’t related to enlistment, but Has anybody here taken the ASTB? I’m taking it next week and I’m very nervous. My naval science instructor told me people recommend going in blind the first time, only recently have I realized that he’s absolutely HAD me and this is a really dumb idea.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57032974
Section 1: MST (Math Skills Test): Nothing you probably haven’t seen before in high-school but, it’s definitely worth brushing up on. You’re going to see some basic arithmetic, geometry, algebra, angles, and perimeter, along with the occasional time and distance word problem and potentially some basic probability.

Section 2: RCT (Reading Comprehension Test): Again, really straightforward stuff. You read a passage of text and are given options of sentences only one of which is totally true based on the text given above. Most will seem true but, only one can actually be derived from the provided passage.

Section 3: MCT (Mechanical Comprehension Test): The questions in this section are similar to what would find in an intro to physics class. Brush up on your knowledge of basic physics and how it relates to velocity, volume, and pressure as well as the mechanics of simple machines when it comes to gears, electricity, and weight distribution.

Section 4: ANIT (Aviation and Nautical Information Test): You guessed it! On this section of the ASTB you’re going to need to know some nautical terminology, a little bit of aviation history as well as some principles of aviation like aerodynamic principles, basic aircraft components, and flight rules

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57033076

Section 5: NATFI (Naval Aviation Trait Facet Inventory): You sort of get off easy here as there’s no real way to prepare for this section. It’s a personality inventory that, in the end, will gauge ones suitability for a career in aviation based on their personal characteristics.

Section 6: PBM (Performance Based Measures Battery): Depending on your tastes this might be the most ‘fun’ part of the ASTB. You basically get to do a flight simulation. You’ll be given a flight mock-up flight console with a throttle and joystick along with a headset. You’ll also get a map that you’ll need to study before guiding an airplane around on a screen. For a more detailed of explanation of this section check out our full-length article of the different sections of the ASTB called ASTB Test Layout.

Section 7: BI-RV (Biographical Inventory with Response Validation): This is the part of the ASTB that you can complete from any computer with an internet connection. It is recommended that you complete this section prior to writing the rest of the ASTB. All it is, is a questionnaire about your previous experiences and successes or achievements with aviation. Like section 5 you really can’t prepare for this section – just answer honestly as there aren’t any real right or wrong responses.

IOW, bitch you should have prepared lel. Don't worry about it, but do study a little about basic history, math, and what you'd find in a toolbox.
