If you do a projection of Ukraine's admission of dead from earlier in the year, 20K is pretty close (only about 5K lower than a straight-line projection). Although combat has intensified the last few weeks, it has peaks and valleys. I can only think of three instances were causalities were known to be high: The first few weeks of the invasion, the second when Russia tried to encircle Sievierodonetsk, and finally during the current push on Bakhmut Only when Russia regroups and regains the initiative for a massive assault does Ukraine seem to take any major casualties. If you're skeptical, consider that almost every estimate has Ukraine sitting around 100K casualties. This estimate wouldn't be far off if Ukraine isn't counting non-serious casualties and all their wounded are completely out of action . If you double the casualty numbers to include non-serious casualties, then you are dead-on for 100K which is in line with every other estimate. For Russia consider that we have repeated heard estimates around 150K-200K in dead and seriously wounded. This is right along those lines. Further, we also know that Russia lacks: proper medical gear, proper evac, proper medical training for soldiers, proper armor/vests/helmets, proper camouflage, protected vehicles, cover for their advances, etc... Russia is the one who is constantly seen on video advancing using human wave tactics into an entrenched enemy. You EXPECT to take at least 3 to 1 casualties in those situations, maybe more. We also know that Russia is taking a 3-to-1 loss ratio in equipment according to the most open and verifiable available data. Personally, if Russia tries to claim anything better than a 3-to-1 casualty ratio in Ukraine's favor, I think they're full of shit.

posts.sub: Turkey picks South Korean transmission for Altay tank
posts.com:
https://www.defensenews.com/industry/2023/02/03/turkey-picks-south-korean-transmission-for-altay-tank/
>ANKARA — A South Korean manufacturer, SNT Dynamics, said this week it will supply transmissions for the engines that will power the Altay, Turkey’s first indigenous tank.

>The subsidiary of SNT Holding announced it has signed a deal with BMC, a Turkish-Qatari partnership that builds the Altay, to supply the EST15K, a 1,500-horsepower automatic transmission. The South Korean company said the export deal includes $74.9 million of supply until 2027 and has an option for further sourcing priced at $141 million between 2028 and 2030.

>SNT said the deal was signed after field tests and assessment, including an endurance driving test last year.

>“It is a valuable achievement through a harsh test evaluation, such as completing a night-based driving of about 200 kilometers (124.27 miles) a day even in the local rough terrain and environment,” the company said.

>The first phase of Altay tanks will be equipped with a Korean power group consisting of a Hyundai Doosan production DV27K diesel engine and SNT Dynamics production EST15K gearbox.

>BMC expects to deliver the first two tanks to the Turkish government in May 2023. Field tests are expected to continue until 2025, both by the Turkish Armed Forces and by contractors.

>Mehmet Karaaslan, general manager of the company, said BMC is slated to turn over eight units a month for an initial batch of 100 units.

>BMC won the multibillion-dollar Altay contract in 2018. That contract provides for a first lot of 250 tanks, life-cycle logistical support and the establishment and operation by the contractor of a tank systems technology center.

Well considering Ukraines situation, id be willing to bet a lot of that gear is privately owned.
As for why militaries still issue boots, it’s because they’re better all around than shoes. For all their faults, if you take good enough care of them, they should last a whole enlistment, or at least half of one, and provide you with at least basic support and cover from elements. Also some people don’t like have nonexistent support and a small puddle completely soaking your foot. I’ll use myself in an example, like two years ago I royally sprained my ankle training, and since then that ankle has been more prone to rolling. So for me, ankle support is really important when buying a boot, it was one of the deciding factors in me buying salmon quest 4 boots

posts.com: Is it worse to be shot 27 times by a 22LR or 9 times by a 9mm? We will assume all shots were to the abdomen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57045470

posts.name: Anonymous

>>57045509
To their abdomen?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57045493
True but if you had a choice between the two options, is there one you think you would have a better shot at surviving?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57045627
no

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57045514

Yeah actually. Its all about shot placement.

A shot to the brain or the heart will kill you outright. A shot to the spine will paralyze you below the point you've been shot. Sufficient damage to the lungs will prevent you from getting oxygen, beyond that the only immediate thing that will kill you is blood loss.

Naturally if you survive the blood loss you might have long term health problems if you get shot in an internal organ and if your digestive system is punctured it can cause septic infections which can kill you pretty rapidly (hours or days).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57045470
They're both pretty bad, any hit to center mass is a real bad time. But objectively 27 shots with a 22 is 4.05 square inches of cross sectionally disrupted tissue while 9 shots with a 9mm is 3.6 square inches of cross sectionally disrupted tissue, so by those metrics I would favor getting shot 9 times with a 9mm. The 9mm probably expands a bit more efficiently, but that is hard to keep track of and there are a lot of extra variables. They both break up bones but the 9mm has the energy to shatter and splinter them (though not dramatically) so some hits to ribs might be more grievous in that case as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57045835
I like your explanation. Thank you

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57045470
Yea ok I see what you're getting at. In your example since there are 0 bones present and the bowels are pretty low resistance it'd depend on the spread of the rounds. If it's close it wouldn't really matter(almost say, like, the pattern of a #4 buckshot blast at HD distances), if things are a bit more spread out then the higher number of projectiles would be worse. Of course the second you start considering better targets with more bones like the chest cavity, head, or if theres an arm holding a weapon pointed at you in the way then that goes out the window. Also say if you're talking soft lead spheres of shot instead of bullets for instance or if anything at all is in between your target and you then you'd probably want the 9 nine millimeters.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57045835
Yea, but a moderate increase in wound volume doesn't mean a moderate increase in effective trauma all the time. Say if you're for instance limited by some outside force limiting the dispersion of the projectiles to a fairly small 1-3" area then you run in to a very important question. If you perforate that <3" area 9 times then any underlying structure is thoroughly fucked up and poked full of holes. Just how much does perforating that same section of surface area 27 times instead of 9 times actually increase disruption of the underlying anatomical structures? That's smaller than the average human heart for instance and a heart with 9 .35" holes through it probably isn't going to loose blood all that much slower than one with 27 .22" holes in it even if that's a whopping 11% additional "wound volume". Of course if there's a good amount of spread that changes things

On the off chance you're not trolling...
Even +P 9mm ammo tops out at about 500 ft/lbs at the muzzle. Maybe a little more.
Meanwhile, Underwood is making normal pressure 10mm 155grain rounds that are producing 775 ft/lbs at the muzzle.
The only place where your "only additional 100ft/lb over 9mm" would come close to applying is with range/target loads and those are still pushing 625 ft/lbs in 10mm. (at least from Underwood anyway).

If you can't handle 10mm recoil then you're the problem, not the cartridge. The FBI was full of pansy ass fucks that couldn't be bothered to practice with their firearms, ate too much grease, and had brittle bones.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57034316
The amount of shot and the powder charge behind it are more important to pay attention to. 1 1/2 oz. of shot traveling at 1200 feet per second is going to ruin your day. Doesn't matter if it's #4 buck or 00 buck. It WILL matter if you get into birdshot at a distance over ~20 feet. So, stay away from birdshot. BB & BBB are the smallest you'd want to go, but they are devastating at typical home defense close range 25 yards and under (usually about 8-10 yards).

Notice that #1 buck is .30 cal. I always liked that as my go-to, but it's tough to find anymore. Single-0 and #1 used to be fairly common.

You want to look for 3" or even 3 1/2" shells so you can fit a little more weight/a few more pellets plus a more authoritative powder charge, so you might get more like 1 3/4 oz. moving at ~1400 fps. Steel will weigh less, but travel faster. If you can find #4 buck in a 3" shell, you might be looking at ~1 5/8 oz. 27 steel pellets moving ~1450 or 1500 fps. It will fuck your day up.

What is a bit easier to find is >>57034439 waterfowl goose loads in 3" or 3 1/2" shells pushing steel BB shot between 1500 to 1600 fps depending on powder, etc. At close range it will still penetrate gypsum board sheetrock walls, but be far less dangerous to anything on the other side. At about 8-10 yards it will make a hole in your target about twice the size of 12 gauge, especially if you're using a modified choke. At ~20 yards that hole will be more like fist-sized. A cylinder or improved cylinder choke will spread slightly, but not much at those ranges. If you're shooting at 30 or more yards you should be using something else, like a slug or a handgun.

tl;dr - #4 or 00 doesn't matter at home defense ranges, the weight & velocity is more important. If penetrating walls is an issue, use smaller shot (#4 buck or BB), otherwise 00 is fine. Too. If you find a few boxes of #1 buck, put them in your stockpile; it's a good option to have. Also some slugs.

Yeah, I realized I mis-typed that after posting. I knew it was more, but I wouldn't have been able to guess the number. The thread was headed off page 10 last time I looked so I figured I'd ignore it.

Since we're going "aktshully" here, aktshully there is some variation. Different wads can have different sized cups if the manufacturer wants to adjust number of pellets & total weight of the shot load. I didn't want to drill down into that confusion.

Of primary importance is total shot weight and total velocity a shell can produce. There are several ways to vary that, so the end-user has to pay attention to those stats and educate themselves a bit. I've hand-loaded shotgun shells for decades and have certainly come up with my own interesting loads.

Off the shelf, look for something that starts around 1400 fps and maybe find something that's into the 1550-ish range. If it's a 2 3/4" shell, it will have less shot, if it's a 3" or a 3 1/2" it will have more. As I mentioned, I like steel shot for self- and home-defense. The added velocity is more important adding extra shot ...

... in MOST situations. That's why the end-user has to experiment & edicate themselves. I've loaded real copper-plate BBs (0.177 vs. 0.180 diameter) into a 2 3/4" shell and "tweaked" the powder load "a bit." It will punch a baseball to softball-sized hole through 5/8" plywood at ~18-20 yards. Easily. My 870 has a 30" mod choke on it for waterfowl, but is loaded in a closet for use at any time. There's a carry satchel with half a dozen other loads in it if I need to reload, whole range of shit from pest control #9 skeet shot up through slugs; gun has 3" steel BB goose shot in it by default.

>>57044538
>#12 bird shot
Um, birds? Hunting doves you can recover enough to eat. There are gauges other than 12, & snake shot in pistols. You'd usually find #12 shot in 28 ga or .410 for small game hunting and pest control. I tried it in skeet a few times. It's not good, #9 or #8 is better.

What is your opinion on banning the us of leaded ammo and plastic shotcups/wads for hunting and only for hunting?

https://www.mlive.com/news/2023/02/michigan-bald-eagles-are-dying-of-lead-poisoning-the-reason-may-surprise-you.html

It doesn't take much lead to sicken or kill a bald eagle, and wildlife rehabilitators say the birds are being poisoned by accidentally ingesting bullets while scavenging carcasses from animals killed by hunters using lead ammunition, reported MLive.

“If you’ve ever seen an eagle that has been poisoned, it’s something you’ll never forget,” said John Buchweitz, nutrition and toxicology section chief at Michigan State University Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory. “The animal may go blind. They can develop tremors. They can lose their ability to fly. It’s a sad statement on the truly adverse effects of a chemical, like lead, on an animal.”

America's national symbol were removed from the endangered species list after a then-controversial federal ban on the pesticide DDT nearly killed off the species, which had dwindled to just 417 nesting pairs in 1963 to more than 300,000 bald eagles currently living in the wild, and conservationists are now sounding the alarm on hunting or fishing with lead-based products.

“We’re going to have to use every available resource to get this out,” said James Manley, executive director of Skegemog Raptor Center. “There’s a lot of steps I think we’re going to have to go through to get enough people on our side where it’s like, okay, let’s quit putting a known toxin into the environment.”

A study published last year found nearly half of bald and golden eagles nationwide tested positive for chronic lead poisoning, and it's the third leading cause of death for the species in Michigan, and research shows the main source is lead ammunition from wild game carcasses and the entrails hunters leave behind from cleaning game in the field.

>>57039407
It’s not, just a lot of poor decisions by Congress. It was originally supposed to be the naval gunfire replacement for the Iowa class which up to that point the Navy still retained enough unique battleship components to reactivate. At the same time function as the next generation of mainline cruiser/destroyer. Problem is the program got very expensive and Congress kept slashing the number of total hulls to build. Originally 32 were to be procured, by the time Congress was done monkey fucking it only three would end up being completed. Which in itself isn’t entirely the worst thing because you get three very advanced destroyers and their unique gun systems, however the advanced gun system used a unique round that was guided. With only three ships in the fleet each individual round would cost $1 million which was infeasible when you can buy missiles for that much. This was made worse by the delays in the rail gun program, The zulmwalt was originally designed to incorporate a railgun once development was done but the program is experiencing metallurgical issues. The rails don’t have nearly the longevity and suffered significant damage during testing. The weapon works, problem is it would require swapping out barrels too often. This means the Zumwalt was built in too few numbers for its unique ammunition to be cost-effective to purchase, and its future railgun refit keeps getting pushed farther and farther back. So now they are just going to remove the guns or at least one of them and replace it with a hypersonic missile pack.

I wish the Navy would just bite the bullet and develop a new battleship class instead of attempting and fucking up the old battleships replacements.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57041526
>The lead ship basically disintegrated
No it didn't you are exaggerating
>forgot the concept of CORROSION
No, they really didn't. For one, there are different types of corrosion. The one typically associated with warships is rust, which is the oxidation of the steel. But the Independence was suffering from electrochemical galvanic corrosion, which is basically a fancy way of saying voltage potential differences when two metals (steel and aluminum used here to make the ship fast and light) are submerged in an eletrolyte (sea water). Its basically constantly undergoing minature arc welding all over its metal contact points (the major ones were near where the steel engines were contact the aluminum hull). The ship builder and the US Navy has experience with this and knows the ways to prevent it. But it seems in an attempt to minimize costs (recall that was the original premise: cheap, fast, modular ships) the design specifications call for this to be excluded. Presumedly the Navy didn't think it would be this severe or that they'd be able to handle it. Clearly they haven't. Now, they've gone back and asked for it to be included on the ships still in production...along with paying for it. Not something you would do if it was a manufactures defect.
> so we'll see how that goes
That was years ago. And strangely, since then, there's been zero issues. I wonder why that could be?
>Also the hulls all crack if it actually goes faster than like, sailboat speed but they claim that's not a big deal.
More exaggerating

Buying a lathe precise enough for bullets and gittin' good costs thousands of dollars and requires dextrous hands. The copper is expensive and needs to be in a specific alloy and form factor before you work it. Lathing copper produces a considerable amount of waste that you can't easily recycle, especially since it's going to be all mixed up with other metals, cutting fluid, and lube. You're going to be constantly adjusting and reloading the chuck because bullet diameters aren't enough to keep the rod from flexing at more than a couple calibers in length. If it does flex, the round is ruined and may damage your weapon.
I mean, there's plenty a reason to get a lathe. Lathing bullets isn't really worth it.

Casting lead requires a setup worth a couple hundred bucks. It's trivially repeatable, the alloys are cheap if not free, and reset between casts is a few seconds. 95%+ of your scrap from a cast is recyclable. A blown cast just goes back in the pot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57036461
There are already copper solids, lots of them. They are usually at a disadvantage because having a denser more compact bullet lets you put more of the bullet outside the case, leaving more room for powder. When using the same weight copper solid as a lead bullet, you usually have to reduce the powder charge because there's less room in the case, because most guns have a maximum cartridge length. Exceptions to this will mostly be found in single-shot rifles, where you can hang a bunch of extra bullet out the front of the chamber, until you hit the rifling, because the cartridge doesn't have to travel inside the gun from a magazine to the chamber.

Manufacturing and detonating explosives for personal, non commercial use does not require a federal explosives license. This is true for all explosive substances.

> Persons manufacturing explosives for their own personal, non-business use only (e.g., personal target practice) are not required to have a federal explosives license or permit under 27 CFR, Part 555.

https://www.atf.gov/explosives/binary-explosives

However, there are federal regulations on the transport and storage of explosives. Tannerite gets around these by being stored and sold as a two-part mix that's not explosive by itself, only being mixed on-site.
